items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for reduced flood risk from high tides however further alerts may be issued over the next few days due to the weather conditions. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert for the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including the tidal River Esk has been issued for today's tides. The area of particular concern is Sandsend, with wind driven wave overtopping expected from 08:00 until 12:15 on the morning tide, and from 20:30 until 00:15 on the evening tide, on Friday 16 September. Strong northerly winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast, especially around Sandsend. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 21:00 today, Friday 16 September, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 19:00 and 00:30 this evening, 16/09/22, and during the morning high tide between 09:00 and 11:00, 17/09/2022, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.
We expect flooding to affect beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. The area most likely to be affected is Seaham Harbour and Docks. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated at 12:00 tomorrow afternoon, 17/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible from 1pm this afternoon, Friday 16th September and over the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. There is a heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced. We have reduced our Flood Alert threshold to reflect this. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 8:30am tomorrow, Saturday 17th September.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible from 1pm this afternoon, Friday 16th September and over the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. There is a heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced. We have reduced our Flood Alert threshold to reflect this. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. The current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 8:30am tomorrow, Saturday 17th September.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Hunstanton with sea spray expected because of strong onshore winds.  Tides will be at their highest at 23:00 today, 16/09/2022.   We expect the wave overtopping to affect the seafront at Hunstanton.  We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
Continuing strong winds may cause additional wave overtopping until after the high tide at 23:00 on 16/09/2022 at Hunstanton.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 2.47 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.43 m. The forecast tide level is 2.90 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is Northwest. The forecast wind strength is Force 6.
This message will be updated after the tide has passed or if the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:00pm and 3:00pm today, Friday 16th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.69mAODN at 2:00pm, Friday 16th September, which is 0.69m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5:30pm today, Friday 16th September.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely Friday evening on 16/09/2022 between 08:30 PM and 11:30 PM.

Areas most at risk include Marine Royal Albert Drive in Scarborough, and exposed coastal roads and promenades where the combination of wave action and spray is expected to cause hazardous conditions. Please be careful along beaches and exposed coastal areas as waves and spray may be unpredictable.

We continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 16/09/2022, or as the situation changes.
